Award.AwardTitle: Track 2: Developing a Sustainable RESESS Program
Award.AbstractNarration: The Research Experience in Solid Earth Science for Students (RESESS) program has established itself as a successful program for multi-year summer research internships for Earth science undergraduates from populations underrepresented in science. Students are recruited in their sophomore or junior year and complete 10-week internships that include research, leadership training, an eight-week communication workshop, multi-faceted mentoring, and a final colloquium. Additional funding through this award is being used to take RESESS to the next level of success by expanding the number of interns, extending the scientific content and geographic reach of the program, and building a model for sustainability based on a program infrastructure with disseminated mentoring. The expanded program will support a minimum of 12 interns per year, with students spending their first two years in Boulder and then transitioning to work with research mentors throughout the United States during their 10-week summer experience. RESESS will continue a successful collaboration with the award-winning Significant Opportunities in Atmospheric Research and Science (SOARS) program. Expansion into a more distributed model of mentoring - necessary because there is no central research facility analogous to the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) for the geology and geophysics community - is being achieved through expanded partnerships. These partners include scientists in the United States Geological Survey (USGS) in Golden, Colorado, at the University of Colorado, Boulder, staff at UNAVCO, and scientists of the UNAVCO and Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS) research consortia, along with new partners in the Colorado Diversity Initiative and the University of California at Santa Cruz. Intern research projects are expected to include topics such as the technical aspects of GPS, analyzing the seismicity of Asian earthquakes, modeling volcanic magma movement, installing GPS networks to monitor regional tectonics, paleoclimate analyses of insect damage to fossil leaves, lineaments in Antarctica, and others. To sustain the program beyond NSF funding, RESESS is exploring the utility of the Business Performance Excellence model, while engaging the community for increased scientific and financial resources and exploring diversified funding sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the five years of this award, UNAVCO—a university-governed consortium fostering geoscience research and education focused on geodesy—supported 41 undergraduate interns through the Research Experiences in Solid Earth Science for Students (RESESS) program. RESESS is a multi-year geoscience research internship, as well as a community support and professional development program. The RESESS internship recruits upper-division undergraduate students from underrepresented groups to spend 11 weeks in Boulder, Colorado during the summer, conducting an independent, original scientific research project. Students who participated in the summer research program also received summer professional development, year-round support from staff, the opportunity to present their results at a scientific conference, and the option to return to the summer program for up to three years. The primary goal of the RESESS program is to increase the number of historically underrepresented students entering the geosciences. RESESS encourages applications from individuals with disabilities, non-traditional students, military veterans, and students who are Black or African American, American Indian or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander, Hispanic or Latino. RESESS alumni are 52% Latino/Hispanic, 27% African American/Black, 9% Native American, 5% Asian American, and 7% Caucasian.

The RESESS program is managed by UNAVCO but draws on the expertise and experience of professionals throughout the greater Boulder, Colorado region, including the University of Colorado-Boulder, Colorado School of Mines, Unites States Geological Survey, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Ecological Observatory Network, University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, and the National Center for Atmospheric Research. In addition, geoscientists from around the country have contributed to the program, including scientists from the University of Nevada-Reno, Cornell University, Syracuse University, University of Oregon, Pennsylvania State University, University of New Orleans, Miami University, University of Miami, and the University of Oklahoma. The 124 science professionals who participated in the program as mentors received training on guiding undergraduate research students as well as guidance on supporting students from populations underrepresented in the geosciences.

The RESESS program has demonstrated that a multi-faceted, multi-year research experience for students from historically underrepresented groups facilitates their success in graduate school and professional geoscience occupations. Emphasis on both professional and research-skill development has enabled students who participated in the RESESS program to excel in diverse professional environments. The program also provided students with the confidence to pursue opportunities they may not have previously considered, leading to broadened participation and engagement of well-trained geoscientists.

Annual program evaluation identified the need for a multi-layered approach to professional development opportunities for students. Program staff developed a multitude of opportunities for interns. RESESS interns participated in professional development opportunities to develop critical thinking skills, learned to read and analyze journal articles, developed scientific writing skills, enhanced scientific and informal communication skills as well as strengthened presentation skills. A formal leadership training session at the beginning of the summer was found to increase student confidence and provide them with tools for addressing conflict as well as help them create their own positive work environment.
